comments:
I replaced the underlying code for Authentication. This code does not loop until
the uer enters the proper userid/password or cancel. It is a one shot try and
the user has to 'refresh' the site if needed.
in this situation, I had a scenario where after seeing the dialog telling me the
authorization failed and closing it, the dialog opened by itself 2 or 3 times.

see following trace

Some traces are valid, some are triggered by 
org.eclipse.update.internal.ui.forms.SiteForm$1.linkEntered

should UI remember a coreException was thrown, or should Core not attempt to
reconnect if UI doesn't explicitly allow ? What if in the case of head-less
application ?

I think that the best way to handle this is if Core would 'remember' that a 
connection to a particular site failed, cache that information and 
return 'null' the next time the request has been made for the site. However, 
this information should be discarded when 'getSite' is called with a request to 
drop cache and reconnect (getSite(URL, boolean)). 

Caching failed attempts in UI is too high up the stack.

What are the exact steps to reproduce this problem?
It is not clear from the comments whether it was fixed or not.

I believe we fixed it. I am not sure how to reproduce it.

In a nutshell, getSite(URL, boolean) can throw an exception.
There is a cache mecanism in getSite that returns the found site isntead of
trying to connect everytime
We should have teh same code where, if an exception is thrown to caller, we
cache this info and return null to teh caller unless getSite(URL, true) is
passed in which case we try to refresh

Does it make sense what I write :)

Thanks Chris.
We actually test the last modified time stamp before returning the cached 
site, just in case the site has been modified on the server.
Closing it.
Dorian, right but what is there is an exception getting the site ?
